title: Living as a Disciple of Jesus Christ in Society
subject: Theology

document.title: Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age

B2376ECCBA054F528FD4E0E6F3E851EE.description: Perfect justice will be realized only in eternal life.

E84375E694A1430ABDBDCB1D40956952.description:
A perfect world cannot be built by human effort
for justice.

950E694A3F434B0BB011905EC6B0C18A.description:
Charity should shape justice to make it Christian;
charity is not extra or optional.

757D54FD22F74EE3992B647C954BCA30.description:
The works of justice do not exclude the works of
charity or vice versa.

7E78EED488E54C9DA52BE1AA71218228.description:
Isn’t it more important to work for justice than to
engage in charity?

177C09802416463C86E460F08D277324.description:
We have the example of the martyrs, which shows
the strength and power that faith and God’s
grace give.

D477258A15264DB092D4CDFF0BE1B2B0.description:
We have the example of Jesus Christ, who in not
fighting back and in forgiving his executioners
showed true strength.

CB9730DD88EF4898B5F4208995BB6BBA.description:
Jesus Christ, in his life and his teaching, challenges
us to see the truth that power and strength are to
be measured in terms of virtue and inner strength.

3825A83E71D145CFB63A35FAD70C96C9.description:
No. It takes a lot more courage and strength to
forgive and not seek vengeance than to fight back
or try to get even.

D136F309375948B0A7A9D2B2D5A30221.description:
Isn’t not fighting back or getting even with someone
who hurts or offends you a sign of weakness?

C957EF4DAF1D4B199D4E44F8AB40C66C.description:
People who find the fulfillment in life which leads
to inner peace and joy are those mature enough
to understand that what really matters is God’s
infinite love for us and what he has taught us about
himself and the meaning of life.

F3D153F9DA704911BF2B2B8F2A8C7BEA.description:
True and lasting fulfillment is never found in
money or material possessions.

64B985F0BB794CA49AAD1A871382473F.description:
Real happiness is found in fulfilling God’s plan for
us.

D807C1D89DCE4B2488F5C816CEAE32B1.description:
While there are many people who build their
lives on such an approach, Jesus Christ, in his
life and his teaching, teaches us that the greatest
achievement is growth in holiness and virtue and
becoming more like him.

EB0FB35790E9485D96853F5B82D4285B.description:
Isn’t the degree of a person’s success and achievement
really measured in terms of financial security and
wealth?

E5257C64718B44B1AD29D8F43F14524D.description:
Selflessness, rather than selfishness, is the
characteristic of a disciple of Jesus Christ, who is
the living embodiment of what it means to live in
a selfless way.

9FBEA34793814C729C2E23AD81EF2404.description:
Living in a self-centered way is one of the effects
of Original Sin. God created us to live and act in
a way that is centered on him and on others,
not ourselves.

4F06FF7AB4684A8AA9BDCB8481E0EB5C.description:
God looks out for every human being. He brings
us into being, watches over us in life, and draws us
to want to live with him forever. Evidence of his
concern can be found in the care for one’s wellbeing often seen in the action of the Church as
well as coming from family, friends, and members
of communities to which we belong.

A295C9ABDAE34E26BF7398C1AAB0BD1C.description:
Why shouldn’t we look out for ourselves first? No one
else will look out for me.

24F14D3B774B447EB5F07F04A4CD5D75.description:
The two Great Commandments: love God with all of
your heart, soul, and mind, and love your neighbor as
yourself (Mt 22:36-40).

91D786A31A524E16B4B64627639C54A9.description:
Witness to Jesus and the Church always;
defend the innocent, even die for your faith.

89BE5FC32D0949579C73660B14212D21.description:
Blessed are those who are persecuted for
righteousness’ sake.

7F72F3FF51CE4F4693CB035FE7D2DF7E.description:
In God’s will is our peace. Perform works
of peace.

334BE3D26D0844C4890A95A9A48F664A.description: Work on virtues of modesty and chastity.

FD9ADFEF7F174B0C9ECE20D1FAECB410.description: Blessed are the pure in heart.

2E22A025461245829AA880542FBCC77F.description:
Blessed are those who hunger and thirst
for righteousness.

A44C57C6DA9649829C79F0F141D6A2BD.description:
Forgive one another. Be quick to ask
forgiveness.

1654DF8F1EB74380A155ED8DA03AFA81.description:
Prone to arrogance and disrespect for
others, violence.

5EC39ECA4E7F42A0AC2144E343B317E9.description:
Self-discipline in the face of evil;
gentleness, unselfishness.

47972FD68B974D48BE1A70948BA1B698.description: Loss of care for the living and defenseless.

0FFB967C25494B5890550F87700B14D5.description: Be compassionate to those in pain.

25E4A24308E04F42955A1E06E22BB754.description:
Otherwise we will tend to materialism,
selfishness, exploitation of others.

4F14ACAF05724A36BBDEAC052C4CE4DA.description:
Choose a lifestyle that benefits those most
in need.

3A79F147DFEC4B04BCCB3E40334B2D69.description: Blessed are the poor in spirit.

4505A48016FB477BB819C03F81EA5668.description:
Social dimensions of the Beatitudes (CCC, nos.
1720-1729).

2862A39C4F7C4B738EB225FE2ED31194.description:
Cultural attitudes that idealize wealth,
materialism.

949FAFFAFAE64B58BA39C0C32EB4CA63.description:
Media, advertising, and exploitation
of lust; “adult” bookstores, Internet
pornography.

338623828A184C79BD561D4D8E7D512D.description: Create conditions for chaste life and love.

68FFD7F0E4584E31AEDDDF22FA7F7147.description:
Lies, detraction, perjury, rash judgment,
violation of professional secrets.

7AF41392735C497DBAD31192E1B37017.description: Promote truth in society and media.

201CA532FED541AFAC06BFD5D53B45AB.description:
Stealing, unjust damage to others’
property, destruction of environment,
enslavement of women and children,
white-collar crime, violation of public
trust, perpetuation of third-world poverty.

558BDC88A3BE4E7DB8FAF0F7292B45E4.description:
Just sharing of goods, qualified right to
private property, just treatment of
workers, stewardship for environment,
just economic policies.

CD5D53C4632549BB8579E6D302C82BEF.description:
Adultery, fornication, masturbation,
homosexual acts, rape, prostitution,
pornography (CCC, nos. 2351-2356).

379BBCC2E16E4E718BA039B91DFD3656.description:
Promote chaste life and love in society,
marriage, family.

DD2E007D760E4BDEAA40AAE4CF98EBBE.description:
Dishonor human life—culture of death.
a) Abortion, euthanasia, physician-assisted suicide, cloning, genetic
manipulation.
b) Teaching on capital punishment.
c) War (conditions for just war),
conscientious objection.
d) Scandal.

C0444407AD1144BC98F370989C790175.description: Fosters a civilization of life and love.

C87750CB953D4D269816A2E472574B06.description:
Anarchy, civil unrest, corrupt government,
ignoring of common good, nonparticipation in democratic society.

CDD114C6DE6C4DF2BE896C511A644BDB.description:
Respect legitimate civil authority,
government care for citizens’ rights,
citizens’ participation in public life,
conscientious objection to unjust laws.

CE51ED62560E4A4F998D28F432CE7B07.description:
The last seven Commandments focus on our
relationship with others: the moral teaching of
our faith must be brought into people’s interaction
with each other (N.B. [1] positive aspects of
commandment, [2] failures to live it).

496A158BD037432CA984DFA0E31501ED.description:
Societal authorities should ensure freedom
of worship.

F8C34DBB7712430C8034AB7E7224072A.description: Duty and the right to freely worship God.

65EADC21D697439AA414BD2A3EA960F9.description:
First three Commandments—relationship with
God (CCC, nos. 2084-2195).

09CE77C5D8BA4D7292883AB6BEE05158.description: The social dimension of the Commandments.

50A60992E4C44AE88179D56B67A9DDA1.description:
Social sin can be passed on to future
generations.

D9D2999ED36C4C80ABC681FCE2D331DC.description:
Social structures which foster unjust treatment
of others.

6AB33CC384BD4A998203D3A352CBE828.description:
Personal choices in response to social
injustice.

D1FE2C3EA37841309AEB35FC1AF81FB9.description:
Personal sin that contributes to social
injustice.

13D5E5FE7D294702B67F1BA754D6C401.description: Social sin stems from collective personal sins.

8C67F16DA8844F5EBDAB60DF2C736E30.description: Personal sin at the root of social sin.

B187CE140C2340B38B556697D48731F4.description:
Difference between “social sin” and personal sin
(CCC, nos. 1868-1869).

A803F07B1A6345BAB18DDE7C3C274E01.description:
Solidarity: individuals should work for the common
good (CCC, nos. 2437-2442).

21118E82F6414BD5B4439B154256DB79.description: Right to work in just conditions.

EC5E934E14614BED9F3D6BF71AB030C0.description: Dignity of work and the rights of workers.

D63DFE2DAEF44467A84C3D1A3C0DD63C.description: Assess social acts and their impacts on poor.

681C2B8D59B14B39A422649B83840C5B.description: Be a voice for the voiceless.

1518AD6D1CB540608EB89E4AFB530144.description: Appropriate use of wealth and other resources.

E4F0E0030E9D4BB3BF683B1766CA6C96.description: See Christ in homeless, outcast, unpopular.

6E65C2071155496ABC86B80A879B2D44.description: Why all need these goods (CCC, no. 2402).

9A92624BDFAA4613BD2BF1A9F8E25730.description: Goods of the earth for every human being.

A6780295FA1D4351B1DBD86A2A29A226.description:
Moral principle: universal destination of the goods
of the earth (CCC, nos. 2402-2406).

C69F09D3481E42349531EDED9E1F8AA7.description: Society should foster and protect these rights.

AD5740C3E91F4B329462946382016F18.description: All have right to life and to what sustains it.

2EFFE75F2AC74B178B6D8F4C2297C862.description:
All people should participate in society—work for
common good.

9ACB17317E3B42DB91637B9C39048455.description: Society should protect dignity and growth of family.

F89CF86BD3A84E90A68D74451483DD8C.description: The family: foundation of society; needs support.

5B2D920FDC4448A790EDC3B5BA4A5912.description: Call to family, community, and participation.

64FF17A8ACB84E85920BE29275B963A6.description:
The Incarnation: Jesus’ identification with each of
us (e.g., Mt 25:45, Acts 9:4).

3C4E2CF37A174EB79562EE443036FBD0.description: Dignity due to being an image and likeness of God.

1019F4C0D93A4F5B9DFDA7C31649B46A.description:
All human life created and redeemed by God
is sacred.

0ACB2ADE10FC465C96911EE46B2A4C1F.description:
Major Themes of Catholic Social Teaching
(CCC, nos. 1877-1948, 2196-2257)

87D179EB0E894800B8468498E6C8D595.description:
Statements on capital punishment: A Good
Friday Appeal to End the Death Penalty (1999);
A Culture of Life and the Penalty of Death
(2005).

52FB9864C1BB4C46815D52663D105B2F.description:
Economic Justice for All: A Pastoral Letter on
Catholic Social Teaching and the U.S. Economy
(1986).

0932AD3F64074675A539410A6BE126C9.description:
The Challenge of Peace: God’s Promise and Our Response (1983); Sowing Weapons of War
(1995).

2158E0402BAE4D7CB430EEDB68BD8888.description: Sampling of more recent pastoral letters.

F506AA8191BC4049BC928FF211BC8D41.description:
After World War I, the bishops of the United
States began a program of social reconstruction
which included teachings on minimum wage, social
security, and worker participation in management.

1331B491EE064AB9A9036F1680CFA34A.description:
United States Conference of Catholic Bishops
(USCCB).

44F2724650154610B644F295034E340D.description:
The peace and security of the group and
its members.

FC1E48CB4FC04F86BE0B9ADB30729D34.description:
Prosperity, or the development of the spiritual
and temporal goods of society.

2583DE61DC144403A463A1B699F0FA28.description:
Respect for and promotion of the fundamental
rights of the person.

774B97742FF246EFB9D3C3E12B622ACF.description:
The perfection of the person by the common good:
man is perfected not only by private goods such as
food and shelter but by “common goods” such as
peace and truth that come about through his life
with others in community (CCC, nos. 1905-1912,
1925-1927).

E5295E6913434193972B5ABEB54678B2.description:
God is the source of all civil authority: man does
not confer authority upon himself, but authority
flows from God to all just governments and laws
(CCC, no. 1899).

127E1E9CCF084A899EDBD7A038D4381F.description:
The necessity of the moral law: the moral law
provides the foundation for all social teaching by
accounting for man’s duties and consequent rights
(CCC, nos. 1959, 2070, 2242).

87A03FCCCE6B48B5B777DE87D938CE4F.description:
Principles of Catholic social teaching from the
Universal Magisterium.

F9DA184CB2ED4FB9B2372BBA9CD62117.description:
Compendium of the Social Doctrine of the Church,
Vatican, 2004.

F70BBA64182D460CB4D4F008E6AE28EE.description:
Social doctrine encyclicals of Popes Pius XI, John
XXIII, Paul VI, and John Paul II.

B8EA6133AB87496AB73196C2ABE25D90.description: Pope Leo XIII: encyclical Rerum Novarum in 1891.

2F1E4E62A6484205A90CFFBD26F29F75.description: Social teaching in the modern era.

317667D5E8AD44A090738472848C7F90.description:
Corporal and spiritual works of mercy
(CCC, no. 2447).

2259EB15E7E943339C3EE616DFD2F03A.description:
Communal sharing, deacons, collections
for churches.

CC7E26200DA64E4D99FF09E01D77C15D.description:
The Sermon on the Mount; Last Judgment
(CCC, nos. 2153, 2262, 2336, 2605, 2830).

8C23729FD8854F509EB5DA859D9F954F.description:
Church always has stood for charity and justice (CCC,
no. 953).

46A76B884E7E4E7BBB9F73E4A09FC238.description: Teacher: forms the social conscience of society.

B51461244BF24A6D85325D10DE461C1D.description: The household of faith—Church as the following:

96B4F148CF9847FEA9B17FD9ABF32471.description:
The social nature of the human person (CCC,
nos. 1878-1889, 1929).

510F042D4CA84CBE92564CC3178176C9.description:
The unity of the whole human race (CCC, nos.
842, 1877).

9239EC70CEB04F08866E259C1ED969AC.description: Witness Christ in words and actions.

45804C6884E84AA5BAE56B4EBE223806.description:
Trinitarian communio is the pattern for social
life (CCC, nos. 267, 738, 1693).

E8B322091439422BB72634A8EB6BA58E.description: Happiness is a shared communion with God.

D4CE5850A8CD44148E808C6261030B48.description: Eternal life with the Triune God in heaven.

770034FFD7BB4B8F9ECDC50F3EAE3D69.description:
God’s Plan for His People: Vatican II: The Church is a sign and instrument of communion with God and the unity of the whole human race
(LG, no. 1).
